author: Jeff Parsons
title: Would you pay for YouTube? Video site launches advert-free option with offline viewing - for a price
text:
Watch this video again Watch Next 
YouTube has unveiled a subscription version of its service that removes the adverts and promises exclusive videos featuring the likes of PewDiePie . 
Called YouTube Red, it's being launched in the US for $9.99 per month - and it won't be long to wait until it arrives in the UK. 
The service will also allow customers to download videos and watch them offline . 
What's more, YouTube is launching a dedicated music channel - YouTube Music - that sits alongside the recently-revealed YouTube Gaming . 
Subscription to YouTube Red covers all the channels and is a direct competition to the likes of Spotify and other streaming services like Netflix . 
"Starting early next year, YouTube Red will get even better with member-only access to new, original shows and movies from some of YouTube’s biggest creators," said Matt Leske, senior product manager at YouTube. 
One of the new shows is called "Scare PewDiePie" and is a reality-adventure series from the makers of the Walking Dead. 
It will see the gaming icon, who's real name is Felix Kjellberg encounter real life situations inspired by his favorite video games. 
YouTube already has over a billion users (those with accounts) and says that hundreds of millions of hours of video are watched each day. 
Would you pay to watch ad-free YouTube videos? 
Plenty of people also use YouTube as a way of finding and playing music. 
And, as a sweetner deal, anyone who buys a YouTube Red subscription will also get a subscription to Google Play Music - Google's other Spotify competitor. 
The new service will go up against other web-based platforms like Vimeo and Dailymotion. 
And they say they aren't worried by today's announcement. 
“There is power in a single channel offering like YouTube’s, but we believe there is better way to empower creators to share in the revenue they generate versus having to compete solely for play count," said Kerry Trainor, the CEO of Vimeo. Poll loading …
